title: Adam Scott glimpses future through the business of golf
text:
James Thomson Columnist Oct 18, 2019 — 9.42am Share

Adam Scott is feeling an extra level of excitement as he prepares for his annual trip to Australia for the summer’s big golf tournaments.

In early December, Scott will again do battle in the Presidents Cup, the biennial event that pits the United States’ best golfers against a team of stars from outside Europe.

“There’s no doubt there’s a big sense of achievement in making these team events,” says Scott, who’s based in the Bahamas. “But it’s kind of a bittersweet one for me because I’ve played on so many losing teams.”

Scott’s hoping for a different result this year behind international team captain Ernie Els. “Ernie’s put in a lot of work behind the scenes to change the script for the international team and hopefully change the outcome.”

Scott has enjoyed another strong year, earning $6 million during the 2019 PGA season. Aged 39, his wealth was estimated at $77 million on last year’s Young Rich List.

A new understanding of his endorsement income has seen his estimated wealth swell to $202 million, putting him in 20th spot on this year’s list.

Adam Scott: "There’s a big sense of achievement in making these team events."

Consistency off and on the course has been a hallmark of a professional career that started in 2000. For much of that time, Scott has enjoyed the backing of three key partners: luxury watch giant Rolex, Japanese clothing group Uniqlo and golf equipment maker Titleist.

Although his focus is firmly on the course, his partnerships give him a rarefied view into the inner workings of some successful companies. Scott cites Uniqlo founder Tadashi Yanai as one of the most impressive business people he’s come across.

“The humility of the man who’s created this huge clothing company is quite impressive. The way he deals with the ups and downs over such a long period and on a global scale; he just handles it so well.”

Although Scott says he’s not contemplating retirement, his sponsors have given him a peek into life after golf. Rolex sponsors the Venice Biennale of Architecture, a subject close to the heart of his wife, Marie Kojzar, who is an architect.

“Development in a broad sense interests me,” he says. “Given the fact I live in hotels, I’m interested in having a really nice boutique hotel that I’d love to stay at.”

The November issue of AFR Magazine, including the Young Rich List, is out on Friday, October 25 inside The Australian Financial Review. Follow AFR Mag on Twitter and Instagram.
